20110119161122.000|20110119161124.000|TR0|CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN BUSINESS 
20110119161124.000|20110119161127.000|TR0|CORRESPONDENT:  Well, you know, Ed 
20110119161127.000|20110119161129.000|TR0|mentioned $45 billion in deals.  The White 
20110119161129.000|20110119161132.000|TR0|House telling us it will support, not 
20110119161132.000|20110119161135.000|TR0|create, but support 235,000 jobs.  And I

20110119164442.000|20110119164445.000|TR0|STEPHANIE ELAM, CNN BUSINESS

20110119164447.000|20110119164450.000|TR0|make sure we help people out as they're 
20110119164450.000|20110119164452.000|TR0|getting along in age to figure it out.
20110119164452.000|20110119164455.000|TR0|
20110119164455.000|20110119164457.000|TR0|So the percentage of workers who actually 
20110119164457.000|20110119164500.000|TR0|said they plan to retire at 70 or older 
20110119164500.000|20110119164502.000|TR0|has tripled in the last decade.  That's 
20110119164502.000|20110119164505.000|TR0|according to the Employee Benefit Research 
20110119164505.000|20110119164508.000|TR0|Institute.  So if you don't want to work 
20110119164508.000|20110119164510.000|TR0|in your 70s, you've really got to start 
20110119164510.000|20110119164513.000|TR0|with that first job.
20110119164513.000|20110119164515.000|TR0|
20110119164515.000|20110119164518.000|TR0|So we spoke with Mary Beth Franklin from 
20110119164518.000|20110119164520.000|TR0|Kiplinger's Personal Finance and she 
20110119164520.000|20110119164523.000|TR0|calculated that if you save just $10,000 
20110119164523.000|20110119164526.000|TR0|at an 8 percent annual return at age 25 
20110119164526.000|20110119164528.000|TR0|and don't contribute anything else for the 
20110119164528.000|20110119164531.000|TR0|next 40 years, at 65 you'll roughly have 
20110119164531.000|20110119164533.000|TR0|$242,000 saved.  But if you start saving 
20110119164533.000|20110119164536.000|TR0|the same amount at age 35, you'll be left 
20110119164536.000|20110119164538.000|TR0|with just $110,000.  Quite a big 
20110119164538.000|20110119164541.000|TR0|difference there.
20110119164541.000|20110119164543.000|TR0|
20110119164543.000|20110119164546.000|TR0|So you 20-somethings out there, make sure 
20110119164546.000|20110119164549.000|TR0|you are enrolled in your 401(k) plan and 
20110119164549.000|20110119164551.000|TR0|maximize your employer's match cause it is 
20110119164551.000|20110119164554.000|TR0|free money after all.
20110119164554.000|20110119164556.000|TR0|
20110119164556.000|20110119164559.000|TR0|And moving up into your 30s, Franklin says 
20110119164559.000|20110119164601.000|TR0|take a portion of each raise and 15 
20110119164601.000|20110119164604.000|TR0|percent of your gross income and put it 
20110119164604.000|20110119164606.000|TR0|towards your nest egg.  If you're buying 
20110119164606.000|20110119164609.000|TR0|your first home and want to borrow from 
20110119164609.000|20110119164612.000|TR0|your 401(k), you can take up to $10,000
